results.title: Kung Fury
results.brief_description: During an unfortunate series of events, a friend of Kung Fury is assassinated by the most dangerous kung fu master criminal of all time, Adolf Hitler, a.k.a Kung Führer. Kung Fury decides to travel back in time to Nazi Germany in order to kill Hitler and end the Nazi empire once and for all.

constellations_other.name: Love of the Glove
constellations_other.description: Looking at the Powerglove's influence on film and television.

results.title: Kung Fu Panda
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Aibel, Raymond Zibach, Glenn Berger, John Stevenson, Mark Osborne and DreamWorks Animation
results.brief_description: When the Valley of Peace is threatened, lazy Po the panda discovers his destiny as the “chosen one” and trains to become a kung fu hero, but transforming the unsleek slacker into a brave warrior won’t be easy. It’s up to Master Shifu and the Furious Five — Tigress, Crane, Mantis, Viper and Monkey — to give it a try.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.title: Kung fu as a folk art
results.creator_credit: Ban Hoe, Pierre Stevens, Roland Pirker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An art, a self-discipline, a martial skill, a philosophy, the ancient Chinese tradition of Kung Fu is all of these. This film follows a class of novices at a Canadian school of Kung Fu through to the completion of their three-year course.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ban Hoe, Pierre Stevens, Roland Pirker and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Kundun
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Refuge Productions, Cappa Productions and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Scorsese’s drama detailing the Dalai Lama’s life story was in development for seven years, with the Dalai Lama having input into the 14 screenplay drafts. With four actors portraying the Dalai Lama at different ages, the film begins in 1933 with the death of the 13th Dalai Lama. Born in a remote area, the new Dalai Lama (seen at ages two and five in early sequences) is observed by monks who determine that he is the 14th reincarnation of the Buddha of Compassion. In 1944 he uses newsreels and Western magazines to study WWII events, and as the war ends, he is forced to deal with Chinese Communist aggression. Mao’s military stranglehold on Tibet eventually forces the Dalai Lama to flee to Dharmsala, India. Commenting on the anti-spiritual…Marxist government of the Chinese Communists, Scorsese remarked, “What interests me is how a man of non-violence deals with these people — that’s ultimately the story.” With a $28 million budget, he re-created Tibet’s tragedy by filming in south-central Morocco with a cast of nonprofessional Tibetan actors. Second unit work took place at locations in Idaho and British Columbia. Cast includes Tenzin Thuthob Tsarong, Gyurme Ththong, Tencho Gyalpo, Tsewang Migyur Khangsar and Sonam Phunstok.

results.title: Kumonosu-Jo = Throne of blood
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description:
Although the spoken word is sparingly used in this reworking of Macbeth, the structure of the play is closely adhered to by retaining the division of acts. Kurosawa plays on similarities between the European and Japanese Middle Ages. There are also essentially Japanese elements. The use of the chorus derives from the Noh drama as does the ritual, closed quality especially in the presentation of Lady Asaji and the witch. The film is ‘founded on the principle of opposition between extreme violence or pathos and moments of static, restrained tension to be found in nearly all of Kurosawa’s films’ (Noel Burch). Also available on VHS and 16mm.

Credits: Director, Akira Kurosawa ; script, Shinobu Hashimoto, Hideo Oguni, Ryuzo Kikushima, Akira Kurosawa ; photographer, Asaichi Nakai ; music, Masaru Sato.
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Isuzu Yamada, Takashi Shimura.

results.title: Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter
results.brief_description: Frustrated with her mundane life, a Tokyo office worker becomes obsessed with a fictional movie that she mistakes for a documentary. Fixating on a scene where stolen cash is buried in North Dakota, she travels to America to find it.

constellations_other.name: Powerful women in the frame and behind the scenes
constellations_other.description: Lady Sarah (Rachel Weisz) exudes power in The Favourite. These female filmmakers and actors do too.

results.title: Kumars at No. 42
results.creator_credit: Nick Wood, Lissa Evans, Sharat Sardana, Richard Pinto and BBC
results.brief_description: Cult television program “The Kumars at No. 42” was an instant success in native Britain. It revolves around a fictional immigrant family who have bulldozed their back garden so they can build a studio on the back of their house and indulge their spoilt only son, Sanjeev, who fancies himself as a celebrity chat show host. Each guest is subjected to a grilling from Sanjeev as well as his mother (Indira Joshi), father (Vincent Ebrahim) and Granny Sushila (Meera Syal). The comedy is quite outrageous as the guests frequently become overwhelmed by the absurd banter between the family and Sanjeev, who tries in vain to take command of his show. Guests include Michael Parkinson, Richard E. Grant, Fay Ripley, Minnie Driver, Garry Lineker, Mel B, Claire Sweeney, Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, Ray Winstone, Richard & Judy, Lorraine Kelly, Stephen Fry and Lesley Garrett.

results.title: Kumak the sleepy hunter: a film based on an old Eskimo tale
results.creator_credit: Audrey McLaren, Alma Duncan, National Film Board of Canada and Dunclaren Productions
results.brief_description: An Inuit legend about a hunter who is too sleepy to hunt, told with puppets. Despite all efforts to change him he remains sleepy until the day when, following a great adventure, he attains success as a hunter. But then he foolishly tells the secret of his success to his nagging wife.

results.title: Kulu: the happy valley
results.creator_credit: R.L. Storey and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: Describes the once remote Kulu Valley in India, its people and their traditional customs and how the district is a hiker’s paradise and popular summer resort. The valley is a trading route for Mongolians with their pack animals, and fairs are major occasions. Pilgrims also make their way to this valley and its sacred temple.
results.creator_credit_for_label: R.L. Storey and Documentary Films of India
